etymology_text:
First attested in Hellenic as Mycenaean Greek ğ€€ğ€µğ€«ğ€¦ (a-to-ro-qo), of uncertain origin. Scholars used to consider it to be a compound from á¼€Î½Î®Ï (aná¸—r, â€œmanâ€) and á½¤Ïˆ (á¹“ps, â€œface, appearance, lookâ€): thus, "he who looks like a man". However, a Î´ (d) would be expected to develop by epenthesis, as in the genitive á¼€Î½Î´ÏÏŒÏ‚ (andrÃ³s), yielding *á¼€Î½Î´ÏÏ‰Ï€Î¿Ï‚ (*andrÅpos). RosÃ©n defends this etymology, positing that the original laryngeal *hâ‚ƒ in the root for á½¤Ïˆ (á¹“ps) (from Proto-Indo-European *hâ‚ƒÃ³kÊ·s) changed the Î´ to its aspirated counterpart Î¸ even across the intervening Ï.
Beekes argues that since no convincing Indo-European etymology has been found, the word is probably of Pre-Greek origin; he connects the word with the word Î´ÏÏÏˆ (drá¹“ps, â€œmanâ€). According to Beekes (2009:xxix), "Shift of aspiration is found in some cases: Î¸ÏÎ¹Î³ÎºÏŒÏ‚ / Ï„ÏÎ¹Î³Ï‡ÏŒÏ‚, á¼€Î¸ÏÎ±Î³Î­Î½Î· / á¼€Î½Î´ÏÎ¬Ï‡Î½Î·".
Garnier proposes a derivation from Proto-Indo-European *nÌ¥dÊ°Ã©rehâ‚ƒkÊ·Ã³s (â€œthat which is belowâ€) (from *(H)nÌ¥dÊ°Ã©r + *-hâ‚ƒkÊ·-o-), hence "earthly, human", for this compare with Proto-Indo-European *dÊ°Ã©ÇµÊ°Åm (â€œearthâ€) whence Latin homÅ, Old Lithuanian Å¾muÃµ (â€œmanâ€), Old English guma (â€œmanâ€).
The word is treated in Plato's Cratylus.
